intro: Crocodeilanthe lancipetala, commonly known as the lance-leaf fern, is a rare and unique species belonging to the family Polypodiaceae. It is characterized by its elongated, lance-shaped fronds that are typically arranged in a compact, rosette-like structure. The plant produces small, spore-bearing structures called sori, which are clustered on the underside of the fronds. Native to specific regions in Southeast Asia, it thrives in moist, shaded environments such as tropical forests. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a valuable but endangered species in botanical studies.
